comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: Looking up King Street towards the intersection of King and Sussex. Photograph taken near the corner of Day Street. Cable tram tracks would indicate the picture was taken before 1900. Google street view maps.google.com.au/maps?hl=en&tab=wl&q=King%20and... The rather grand building on the corner was a branch of the former Bank of New South Wales (now Westpac) The workmen seem to be doing something with the cable tram tracks (which can be seen in the right foreground). The cable tram terminated at Erskine Street, after turning into Day Street (as did the electric trams when introduced in 1902 or 1903 (?); this was the city end of the line servicing the eastern suburbs. This area now covered by the 'City North' exit of the Western Distributor.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: What a great image. I've seen a few of the Caledonian but not this one.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I'm almost 100% certain this was taken in 1900 - during the bubonic plague scare inspired cleanup of Sydney's streets. Compare this one from the Plague Albums - 55. Rubbish at foot of King-street [SLNSW: a147055] Quite possibly an unattributed John Degotardi, Jr. photograph? Similar photos from the albums: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823637&am... acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823637&am... acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823637&am... acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823637&am... acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823644&am... acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823637&am...

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47201412@N02] I think you're right - the cable trams were still running then. What a great selection of pictures you supplied to support your argument, the picture of Kent Street is amazing and brought back many memories, I worked in one of the buildings shown (No 383) on the right (western) side in the 1970s and early 1980s - now its a car park! It had a wonderful lift dating back to 1900 or earlier all brass and wood, the gate had a most wonderful rattle. I think the lift-driver ("Taffie") was an original too!

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: It doesnt look like building tramtracks,  it looks like cleaning up rubbish in the street.  My guess would be during one of the ratcatching efforts c.1900.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: After seeing pellethepoet's posting I think you're right.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Great work! I also think it is a non-Plague Album photo by John Degotardi Jnr. The photographer was extremely clever in turning what would have been a shot of guys cleaning up rats into a work of art. The use of perspectives to frame the picture is stunning (like a William Hogarth print), and the strong "X" lines intersecting at the subject, the barrel of disinfectant (Formalin ?), is inspired - you don't realize it until it is pointed out. I think it is Thursday 5 April 1900, around noon from the shadows. There are daily newspaper reports about the Bubonic Plague and cleansing operations which make for interesting reading. The relevant dates for the King Street area are below. SMH 6/4/1900 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14303969 SMH 7/4/1900 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14304481 SMH 9/4/1900 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14304637

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] There is a small stretch of King Street to the west of the Western Distributor. The Google street view at the corner of what is now Shelley Street and King Street is an equivalent view to the original photo. You can just see the top of the old Bank at the corner of Sussex St, but the rest is nothing short of awful - g.co/maps/u9csv

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]  Footnote (and to make sure the historical record is straight). The cable trams gave way to electric trams on the King Street service on 14 January 1905.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Pretty stunning that it looks like you may have narrowed down the year to a precise day for the photo. I don't think State Records NSW were expecting that!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Perhaps you know how the cable trams turned around at the end of a line? There doesn't seem to me the necessary wide loop or shunting lines marked on the 1895 map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0... .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] It's very easy with Trove and as few as possible search words (in this case "plague king street'). BUT I now think it is the day before, Wednesday, 4 April 1900. For some reason this report from the previous day did not show up in the search, and talks about - " At tho lower end of King-street there is an immense heap of old timber taken from back yards in the vicinity It is stacked on the tramline, and cannot ba burned thero because of damage to the tramway. The burning of rubbish was yesterday a work of considerable danger, owing to the high and gusty wind which prevailed, and it was therefore sus- pended " SMH 5/4/1900 page 5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14303911

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] Re the trams turning in King Street. Whilst I'm not an expert on cable trams I would imagine that it would have been a fairly simple crossover arrangement between the two tracks. However I'm not sure of the technicalities - more research required!

However, it will interest you to know however, that two months later, on the 19 March 1905 the King Street line was extended via Day Street to Erskine Street where a balloon loop with a siding was constructed for use by the new J-class electric trams which replaced the cable cars. My 1921 map shows the loop being at the 'Balmain Jetty'. I have a copy of a 1948 map which confirms the use of the balloon loop after WW2

Here is a J-class car, preserved at the Sydney Tramway Museum

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/9028007@N05/5481801956/in/pool-1375966@N24/]

The Js also ran extensively on the Manly system in the early years.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Thanks, I did know about the Erskine St extension from research into this photo - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4402295061/] The best photo of a cable tram I have ever seen is in the Phillips collection at the PhM. Press Zoom and Full Page - you can see what they are all thinking - wow! - from.ph/385716 . It looks like there is a cross-over track and the driving car is a pushmi-pullyu.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] There were only two cable trams lines in Sydney - the King Street line (which ran to the eastern suburbs) and the North Sydney line which ran from Milsons Point to Ridge Street. Melbourne on the other hand had an extensive city cable car network and the electric cars were used as extensions to this network. I agree the pic you've provided goes a long way to answering the question. I'll still do the research however.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Good on you!  I don't have the patience or eyesight to do it.  I thought I had corrected the blockquote above, but I see now that I missed heaps - shows how we don't really read every letter.

The articles listed above explain a lot of these Plague photos, and help dating many around Sussex Street to April 1900.  For instance the Union 'Shed' was used as the workers' barracks -

However,  the chocolates go to beachcomberaustralia for finding the exact date of the image 4 April 1900.

comment.author: 61425063@N08
comment._content: From the photo above from the Mitchell Library (Rubbish at the bottom of King Street) it is possible to read the sign over the door of the bank building, it is The City Bank. The building on the opposite corner across Sussex Street coming down the hill is the Commercial Hotel, run for many years by members of the Yeend family. Next is a shop run by W. Huggett and as it is advertising the Sydney Morning Herald it is probably a newsagent. Next is the Caledonian.
